title: Multi-focus - toothpaste use of placebo binomial

content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. Consider a study designed to investigate the following claim. A toothpaste with an active ingredient is effective in reducing plaque buildup on teeth. Two designs are proposed for the study. Option <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> Option <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math> Obtain <math alttext="170" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>170</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers from the population of people with plaque buildup on their teeth. Randomly assign <math alttext="90" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of the volunteers to use the toothpaste with an active ingredient each day. Assign the remaining <math alttext="80" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers to use a placebo each day. Observe the number of people who experienced a reduction of plaque buildup in each group after six months. Randomly select <math alttext="170" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>170</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people from the population of people with plaque buildup on their teeth to use the toothpaste with the active ingredient each day and observe the number of people who experienced a reduction in plaque buildup after six months. (a) Give an example of what people assigned to use a placebo in Option <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> might be asked to use instead of the toothpaste with an active ingredient. Explain the benefit of the placebo in the context of the study.

Randomly select <math alttext="170" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>170</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people from the population of people with plaque buildup on their teeth to use the toothpaste with the active ingredient each day and observe the number of people who experienced a reduction in plaque buildup after six months. (a) Give an example of what people assigned to use a placebo in Option <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> might be asked to use instead of the toothpaste with an active ingredient. Explain the benefit of the placebo in the context of the study.

(b) For which option can the results of the study be generalized to all people with plaque buildup on their teeth? Explain, in the context of the study, the characteristic of the option that allows for this generalization.

A researcher conducted the study described in Option <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and estimated the difference in the proportions of people similar to those in the study who would experience a reduction for the two treatments. Assume all conditions for inference were met. The resulting <math alttext="98" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>98</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval (Toothpaste with Active Ingredient minus Placebo) is <math alttext="0.09 plus or minus 0.14" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.09</mn><mo>Â±</mo><mn>0.14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(c) Does the <math alttext="98" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>98</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval provide evidence to support the claim? Justify your answer.

(d) Suppose that the researcher instead decided to compute a <math alttext="99" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>99</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval for the same sample data. Would this change impact your answer in part (c)? Explain your reasoning.

The researcher plans to randomly select people from the study, one at a time and without replacement, to be interviewed. The interviews will continue until <math alttext="25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people who had received the toothpaste with the active ingredient are interviewed. Let the random variable <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the total number of people interviewed.(e) Explain, in the context of the study, why the random variable <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> does not follow a binomial distribution.
